qas.question: When multiple pumps are connected in series to produce higher vacuum it is called what?
The choice of seals, or chamber geometry ,for example impact a pump. Together these are options are called what?
What are two other relevant characteristics of a pumping system along with final pressure?
How can chamber geometry be connected?
What can oil contamination be dependent on instead of pump nature?
How do leakage rates usually happen?
What do certain gases usually help a pump achieve?

plausible_answers.text: reliability, or tolerance to high leakage rates

qas.question: What are two other characteristics of a seal?

context: The lowest pressure that can be attained in a system is also dependent on <b4_0>many things<b4_0/> other than the nature of the pumps. Multiple pumps may be connected <b3_0>in series<b3_0/>, called <a0_0><b5_0>stages<b5_0/><a0_0/>, to achieve <b6_0>higher vacuums<b6_0/>. The choice of seals, chamber geometry, materials, and pump-down procedures will all have an impact. Collectively, these are called <a1_0>vacuum technique<a1_0/>. And sometimes, the final pressure is not the only relevant characteristic. Pumping systems differ in <a2_0>oil contamination, vibration<a2_0/>, preferential pumping of certain gases, pump-down speeds, intermittent duty cycle, <b7_0>reliability, or tolerance to high leakage rates<b7_0/>.
